PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
CAM: Public-Private Partnership Development Project 
December 2012 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The PPTA will be implemented to prepare the scope of activities for the loan project. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The key output of the PPTA is a report containing: (i) proposals for strengthening the 
enabling environment for PPP, with particular reference to the development of the PPP Unit, 
RMU,  PDF,  and  VGF;  (ii)  method  to  identify  viable  PPP  projects;  and  (iii)  framework  for 
preparing and transacting, and managing the projects. These outputs will provide the basis for 
the preparation for the loan project. See Table A4.1.

IV  and  TASF-Others.  The  government  will  provide  in-kind  contributions  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, office space, and other administrative support. The detailed cost estimate is in

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  A combination of individuals and a firm will be engaged for a total of 48 months. The 
selection method for the firm will be QCBS using simplified technical proposals. The selection 
method for selecting individual consultants will be CQS. See Table A4.3.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the project preparatory TA consultants are as follows.  
 
a.  Project Team Leader Consultant (International, 5 person-months) 
6.  The  International  project  Team  Leader  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of 
international  experience  in  development  finance,  project  management,  developing  and 
reviewing  project  proposals,  and  understanding  of  institutional  structures,  operating 
mechanisms, and funding requirements. The expert should have worked in a variety of regions 
and developed a knowledge base and expertise in working with key government agencies at the 
national  and  subnational  levels  and  resolution  of  PPP  project  implementation  issues.  The 
consultant, in coordination with national consultants, will: 
 
(i)  identify and implement the institutional requirements for establishing the PPP 
Unit, RMU, PDF, and VGF and guarantee mechanism; 
(ii)  identify and implement the institutional requirements for the procurement and 
financial management of consultants under the PDF; 
(iii)  identify the requirements for reviewing and processing PPP projects, and prepare 
guidelines to define these procedures; 
(iv)  review subproject applications from GCAs and provide recommendations to the 
PPP Unit under the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) to develop a project 
pipeline; 
(v)  prepare project loan documents to support the establishment of the PDF, VGF, 
and Guarantee Mechanism; 
(vi)  assist the PPP Unit and RMU in their activities and provide training, technical, 
financial and project management-related advice as needed;  
(vii)  liaise  with  other  government  agencies,  development  partners  and  ADB  on 
project-related matters; 
(viii)  supervise international and national consultants on aspects relating to preparing 
TORs,  procurement,  document  processing,  quality  control,  and  financial 
disbursement; 
(ix)  develop detailed selection criteria for subproject applications under the PDF, 
monitoring system to track subproject applications, disbursements,   ensuring 
quality of submissions, and maintaining all documentation/ transaction records;   
(x)  identify  mechanisms  for  maintaining  an  audit  trail  and  all  necessary 
documentation for tracking for audit purposes; 
(xi)  organize,  as  needed,  consultation  and  dissemination  workshops  and  related 
activities;  
(xii)  prepare quarterly reporting format on all disbursements and related activities. 
 
b.  Procurement Specialist (International 3 person-months) 
7.  The international procurement specialist will directly work with the national procurement 
specialist. S/he will carry out an appraisal of all procurement procedures required to support the 
recruitment of consultants under the PDF. S/he will scrutinize the bidding documents, and also, 
including but not restricted to: 
(i)  support the Team Leader in planning and implementing necessary activities to    
develop the procurement capacity of the PMU for recruiting consultants under the 
PDF and GCAs utilizing consultants engaged under the PDF. 
(ii)  support the Team Leader in the preparation of the project loan.

4 
(iii)  carry out training at the PPP Unit, and GCA level on ADB’s regulation in terms of 
procurement. 
(iv)  define a time table for each type of procurement procedure envisaged, and make 
sure that all bidding documents are ready on time and in conformity with ADB’s 
procedure requirements. 
(v)  supervise,  with  assigned  national  procurement  specialist(s),  all  the  tender 
openings as observer. 
 
c.  Financial Management Specialist (international 3 person-months) 
8.  The  international  financial  management  specialist  will  directly  work  with  assigned 
national financial management specialist and other related international and national specialists 
to carry out assessments of financial management capacity building requirements of the PPP 
Unit, RMU and GCAs, including but not be restricted to: 
(i)  support  the  Team  Leader  in  planning  and  implementing  necessary  works  to 
enhance  financial  management  capacity  of  the  PPP  Unit,  RMU  and  GCAs 
engaging consultants under the PDF, or provision of government support through 
the RMU. 
(ii)  support the Team Leader in the preparation of the project loan. 
(iii)  review information system and procedures, propose appropriate improvements 
and reforms. 
(iv)  conduct  FM  capacity  assessments  of  the  relevant  entities  and  suggest  to 
incorporate the design of the disbursement arrangements/fund flow mechanism 
for the ensuing project, based on such assessment. 
(v)  prepare and perform a financial managing development program to develop or 
modernize the information management systems of the PMU, RMU, and GCAs.  
(vi)  prepare a program of on-the-job financial training seminars and courses for the 
staff of the PPP Unit, RMU and GCAs responsible for financial management.  
(vii)  cooperate with the workshop and training consultants recruited under the PDF to 
closely integrate with the on-the-job training assignments. 
(viii)  carry out an appraisal of the Application Forms submitted by GCAs to PPP Unit 
and RMU on their financial aspects, and make necessary recommendations if 
needed. 
 
d.   PPP Legal Specialist (international 3 person-months). 
9.  The consultant will design bid processes, tender guidelines, risk allocation structures, 
project documentation, and bid evaluation procedures. Activities include:  
(i)  review institutional requirements for implementing PPPs from a legal perspective; 
(ii)  assess capacity in the PPP Unit, RMU and prospective GCAs to address legal 
and/or procurement issues;  
(iii)  help PPP Unit, RMU and selected GCAs identify staff to be responsible for 
PPP-related contract design, procurement, and contract management activities, 
and examine capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(iv)  review, identify, design, and provide training to the PPP Unit, RMU and selected 
GCAs on (a) bid documents (requests for qualification and for proposal) and 
contractual  agreements;  (b)  project  marketing  and  prebid  consultations;  (c) 
bidder qualification and bid evaluation criteria;  
(v)  monitoring and evaluation frameworks; (e) required due diligence documents for

Appendix 5  5 
 
potential financiers; (f) bid process, bid evaluations, and contract negotiations; 
and (g) contract management; and 
(vi)  support the Team Leader in the preparation of the project loan. 
(vii)  provide  any  other  training  and  project  development  support  as  deemed 
necessary by ADB.  
  
e.   Technical Specialists (international 5 person months).  
10.  The  consultants  will  prepare  guidelines  to  review  and/or  prepare  the  technical 
assessments  of  project  design  and  cost  estimates,  and  support  capacity  development  in 
prospective GCA entities to:  
(i)   identify relevant staff in PPP Unit, RMU selected GCAs who will be responsible 
for reviewing or preparing PPP technical activities and identify capacity gaps and 
resource constraints;  
(ii)  review, identify, design, and provide training on the preparation of prefeasibility 
studies and outline business cases, and evaluation of private sector bids on 
parameters such as verification of assumptions, population coverage, losses, 
current and projected demand for project outputs, technical viability of the project 
design criteria and standards, capacity, whole of life costs (inclusive of project 
preparation, regular and periodic maintenance and decommissioning costs), site 
requirements, and other conditions;  
(iii)  support PPP project development and evaluation by providing inputs and quality 
control on project costs (capital expenditures, operation, maintenance), required 
contingency, and other information as requested;  
(iv)   support project technical analysis by developing relevant processes, procedures, 
templates, case studies, and financial models to support PPP development;  
(v)   provide  training  on  technical  issues  impacting  on  proposed  PPP  project 
structures such as project costs, and preconditions for a private operator to fulfill 
in meeting service obligations;  
(vi)   provide forums to disseminate information from comprehensive technical reviews, 
including details on projected capital expenditure, operation and maintenance 
costs and their economic costs and benefits; and confirm the project design on a 
least-cost and whole of life cost basis in financial and economic terms;  
(vii)   provide training on such subjects as quantity and rates for major civil works, 
equipment, construction and supervision consulting, and other input items;  
(ix)  support the Team Leader in the preparation of the project loan. 
(x)  provide  any  other  training  and  project  development  support  as  deemed 
necessary by ADB.  
 
f.  Safeguards Specialist (international 3 person months) 
11.  The  consultant  will  prepare  guidelines  and  support  capacity  building  in  project 
environmental and social safeguards in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) and other requirements. The consultant will also undertake capacity building efforts to 
ensure that the executing agency, other involved government agencies/ministries particularly 
GCAs, and the private sector partners understand safeguards requirements for the projects to 
be funded under the loan. The consultant will: 
(i)  in close coordination with the EA and in consultation with relevant government 
agencies/ministries  specifically  GCAs,  prepare  an  environmental  assessment

6 
and  review  framework  (EARF)  consistent  with  ADB’s  Safeguards  Policy 
Statement, 2009 (SPS) and formats described in SPS Annex 1 to Appendix 4. 
The EARF should: 
a.  document potential environmental impacts for sectors/project types identified 
in the pipeline if the pipeline is available at the PPTA stage, including draft 
generic environmental management plans (EMPs) by sector/project type; 
and 
b.  identify implementation arrangements specifying roles and responsibilities for 
undertaking screening and environmental assessment, and environmental 
safeguards during implementation for projects using loan proceeds as project 
investments. 
(ii)  in close coordination with the EA and in consultation with relevant government 
agencies/ministries specifically GCAs, prepare a resettlement framework (RF) 
consistent with ADB’s SPS Annex 2 to Appendix 4. The RF should: 
a.  identify implementation arrangements specifying roles and responsibilities for 
undertaking  screening  and  resettlement  planning,  and  resettlement 
safeguards during implementation for projects using loan proceeds as project 
investments; and 
b.  because impacts on indigenous peoples (IP) are not anticipated, the RF 
should  include  procedure  for  screening  IP  impacts  and  providing  a 
mechanism  for  ensuring  that  projects  with  IP  impacts  will  not  use  loan 
proceeds as project investments.  
(iii)  assist the EA and other involved government agencies/ministries specifically 
GCAs in identifying staff who will be responsible for environmental and social 
safeguard activities, and identify capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
 (iv)  on the basis of the analysis in item (iii), provide training for the EA and other 
involved  government  agencies/ministries  specifically  GCAs  in  ensuring 
compliance with  the EARF and RF;  
(v)   using  draft  EMPs  in  item  (i),  conduct  training  on  EMP  preparation,  and 
incorporating EMPs in tender and contract documents, and how to supervise the 
preparation of or review of contractors’ environmental management action plans; 
and conduct compliance monitoring and reporting;  
(xi)  Join the ADB PPTA review mission and loan fact-finding mission, and provide 
other advice and deliverables as required by  ADB.  
 
g.  Economist (international 2 person months).  
 
12.  The consultant is to prepare guidelines on the economic analysis of PPP projects and 
support capacity development in PPP Unit, RMU prospective GCA entities. Such work will 
include the following:  
(i)   undertake an analysis of relevant infrastructure sectors and subsectors to assess 
their readiness for PPPs;  
(ii)   identify  relevant  staff  in  selected  PPP  Unit,  RMU  and  GCAs  who  will  be 
responsible for preparing or reviewing PPP economic analysis activities, and 
identify capacity gaps and resource constraints;  
(iii)  review, identify, design, and provide training to members of the PPP Unit, RMU 
and  GCAs  on  methodologies  for  determining  project  rationales,  market 
structures, and economic costs and benefits for PPP projects;  
(iv)  support PPP project development, provide inputs on project costs, benefits, key

performance indicators, and any other information as requested;  
(v)   support project economic analysis by developing relevant processes, procedures, 
templates, case studies, and financial models that can be used to support PPP 
development;  
(vi)   provide  training  on  economic  issues  impacting  on  proposed  PPP  project 
structures;  
(vii)   participate in forums to disseminate information on economic analyses, including 
details on projected costs and benefits from a project; confirm the project design 
on a least-cost and whole of life cost basis in economic terms;  
(xii)  support the Team Leader in the preparation of the project loan. 
(xiii)  provide  any  other  training  and  project  development  support  as  deemed 
necessary by ADB.  
 
h.   National  Consultants.  National  consultants  for  24  person  months  will  be 
recruited to provide support to international consultants. Detailed Terms of References 
will be developed.  
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) will be the Executing Agency. A senior 
MEF official will be appointed as project director.  
 
14.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.3. The 
TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Handbook (May 
2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  TA  implementation  period  is  01  March  2013  -                  
30 September 2014.
